p.#text: It is interesting to inquire how far the influence of the   Art.poets can be traced in such works of Greek art as are concerned with the tragic end of Ajax. A favourite subject was the actual contest for the arms. Some red-figured vases, of the fifth century B.C., show Ajax and Odysseus vehemently disputing the possession of the prize,ready, indeed, to rush at each other, while their friends on either side hold them back: Agamemnon, as judge, stands between them. This type seems to have been created, or at least developed, by the vase-painter  . But an earlier form of the same subject occurs on black-figured vases of the sixth century B.C. Here there are only the three principal figures,Ajax, Odysseus, and Agamemnon,and the  for the arms approaches still more nearly to the character of a fight. The competitors are advancing against each other with drawn swords, while Agamemnon tries to keep them apart. The black-figured vases prove that the original literary source was not the  of Aeschylus, as the red-figured vases would have allowed us to suppose, but some older poem. Other works of art represent the close of the contest. A relief on a sarcophagus found at Ostia shows Odysseus seizing the arms which have just been awarded to him, while Ajax, escorted by indignant friends, is retiring, with visible fury in his eyes,the  of the . The same moment is depicted on a vase in the British Museum: Athena herself presides over the court, indicating the artist's literal interpretation of the verse in the  (11. 547 ). On a stone in front of the goddess are seen the  by which the arms have just been adjudged to Odysseus,a detail which recalls the language of Pindar and Sophocles, who both speak of the award as decided by ballot.

p.#text: The painters Parrhasius and Timanthes ( 400 B.C.) are said to have competed at Samos in an , the subject of their pictures being Ajax and Odysseus contending for the arms. But the famous picture on this subject was by Timomachus of Byzantium, whose work was directly inspired by Sophocles. It represented Ajax, as the poet describes him,  sitting among the slaughtered cattle, and brooding on selfdestruction, in that gloomy despair which followed his frenzy. An epigram in the  attests the vivid impression which this picture made on the beholder. It was kindred in conception to another celebrated work of the same painter, Medea meditating the murder of her children. Both pictures were at Cyzicus in the early part of the first century B.C.; they were purchased by Julius Caesar, and placed in the temple of Venus Genetrix at Rome. Ovid in exile remembered both:

p.#text: (3) It has been noted by G. Wolff and others that several words and phrases in the  are Aeschylean:  v. 56  (  etc.): 412  ( ): 447  ( ): 673  ( ): 740  (  etc.). Again, the epic  (172, ) occurs also in  , but not elsewhere in Tragedy; the Doric and epic plural  (1404), used by Aeschylus (  etc.), is not elsewhere used by Sophocles. The , it will be seen, furnishes most of these parallelisms. But such coincidences merely show that the  belongs to a period when Aeschylus had a strong influence on the younger poet's style; and we have no means of setting an inferior limit to that period. In so far, then, as the language of the play has an Aeschylean stamp, it seems more accurate to say that this characteristic is entirely consonant with the hypothesis of a relatively early date than to claim it as a separate indication of such a date. With regard to the epic  and , it should be remembered that the play contains several phrases which show a deliberate aim at epic colouring, such as  (177),  (374 f.),  (933),  (954),  (1165), which the poet may have deemed appropriate to a subject taken from the Trojan cycle and concerned with a Homeric hero.

p.#text: (4) Some critics have thought that only twelve choreutae were used in the , and infer that the play belonged to a time when Sophocles had not yet raised the number of the Chorus to fifteen. The chief ground of this theory is the fact that verses 892914 and 938960 (taken together) contain twelve utterances of the Chorus. It is assumed that each utterance represents a single choreutes. But this is an assumption only; and it does not appear a probable one, when it is observed that verses 900903, and 908914, are passionate expressions of a feeling common to the whole Chorus, and would naturally, therefore, be given by the whole Chorus. In verses 866878, again, the attempt to distinguish twelve parts, one for each of twelve choreutae, involves a highly arbitrary process. The mere fact of  being there employed proves nothing; for the use of hemichoria occurs in plays written at a time when the number of the tragic chorus was certainly fifteen (   ff.,  111, 232).

(5) Lastly, it has been supposed that the play was written not long after the introduction of a third actor, because three actors are on the scene together only in the prologue (Athena, Odysseus, Ajax), and at the end (Agamemnon, Teucer, Odysseus); Odysseus being silent while Ajax is present (92117), and Teucer while Agamemnon is present (13181373). But it appears very unsafe to assume that these facts indicate an early and tentative stage in the use of the third actor. They may be due simply to the construction of the play and to the requirements of each dramatic situation.

p.#text: As between the  and the , the claim to priority would rest with the , if the form of the Parodos were the test; though the Parodos of the  is also of an early type (see n. on  ). But much more weight is due to the fact that the , alone of the seven plays, rigorously adheres to the practice of Aeschylus, in never admitting the division of an iambic trimeter between two or more speakers  (). This was no trivial detail, but a general rule of composition which materially affected the character of dialogue. When Sophocles at last decided to relax that rule, the result was a marked gain in lightness and rapidity at moments when the dialogue became animated or excited. The fact that he had made this change before he wrote the  seems clearly to indicate that the  is later than the

p.title: Ajax
p.#text: Aristotle's work  called  was a chronological list of tragedies and comedies produced at Athens, the list being based on official records contemporary in each case with the production. Similar works were afterwards compiled by Callimachus ( 260 B.C.) and others. The  of Aristotle and of Callimachus are known to have been still extant in the second century A. NowD. , we learn from the Greek Argument to the  that in the Didascaliae the play was styled simply . This is conclusive as to the original title; since, whether the Didascaliae meant, be Aristotle's, or one of the later works, in any case the ultimate authority for the statement dates from the time when the play was produced. In the extant manuscripts the title is  (alluding to the lash which Ajax carries in the first scene); as it is also in the citations by Zenobius ( 130 A.D. ), Athenaeus, and Clement of Alexandria. On the other hand, the Greek Argument states that Dicaearchus (a pupil of Aristotle) called the play , which he could scarcely have done if the title  had already obtained currency. We may infer from these facts that the epithet  was added by some Alexandrian scholar whose authority sufficed to establish it as a permanent part of the title. If the object had been merely, as the author of the Argument suggests, to distinguish the play from the  of Sophocles,  might have seemed a fitter designation; but doubtless the intention was rather to distinguish it from later dramas on the same subject, such as those of Astydamas, Carcinus and Theodectes.

Scene:Before the tent of Ajax, at the eastern end of the Greek camp, near Cape Rhoeteum on the northern coast of the Troad.  ODYSSEUS is closely examining footprints on the sandy ground.  ATHENA is seen in the air (on the ).

p.title: Dict. of Ant.
p.#text: According to the rule of the Greek theatre, the side of the scene on the spectator's right represents the home-region, in this case, that of the Greek camp. To the spectator's left is the region of the open country, stretching east and south from the camp, over the plain of Troy, towards those Mysian highlands from which Teucer returns (v. 720). Aristotle speaks of  as an invention distinctive of Sophocles ( : see Smith's , new ed., vol. II. p. 816). And the words in v. 4, , rather suggest that the Greek camp was somehow indicated here,perhaps with a glimpse of the Hellespont, and of Cape Rhoeteum. It is not known whether the theatre of the fifth century B.C. had ,those triangular prisms on pivots, with scenery painted on each of their three faces, which served as movable side-scenes. A periaktos on the spectator's right could have been used to show the camp. Or, if this resource was not then available, the purpose may have been effected by painted hangings on the back-wall, which, in the fifth century B.C., was probably a temporary structure of wood. With regard to the change of scene after v. 814, see note on 815.

p: Prologue. Athena confirms the surmise of Odysseus as to the guilt of Ajax; shows her favourite his afflicted foe; and points the moral.

Hist. An.
p.#text: . According to Aristotle, the Laconian dogs were crossbred with foxes (,  8. 28, p. 607  3). He describes them as a small breed, with long nostrils and keen scent (:  5. 2, p. 781  9). They were the best hunting dogs, as Pindar testifies, fr. 106:  [ ] . The Molossian dog is often associated with the Laconian (     3. 405 ); but Aristotle tells us that the Molossian breed had no special merit for sporting purposes; its best product was the large sheep-dog. The chief points common to the Laconian and Molossian breeds were courage and pertinacity ( and ,   9. 1, p. 608  31).

p.title: Hippolytus
p.#text: . The general sense of  here is, far from my sight; the question is whether this means, (1) seen only at a distance, dimly seen; or (2) unseen. I formerly preferred the first view, for which we may compare  , , to watch the weather near our ship, rather than from afar. But I now feel two difficulties which it involves. (1) The emphasis on voice and thoughtis so strong as to imply that he does not  her, even at a distance. (2) There can be no doubt that she was visible to the audience. She was probably on the ,a sort of platform, which projected from the wings, at the back of the proscenium, and close to its upper edge. If, then, Odysseus spoke of her as seen only afar,a dim vision in the clouds,the effect would be scarcely happy for the spectators, whose eyes could measure the actual distance between goddess and hero. On the other hand, there would seem nothing strange in her remaining invisible to him. In the , Aphrodit speaks the prologue, and was certainly visible to the spectators; but not to Hippolytus, who says, .

When Ajax comes forth, he, indeed, appears to see her (v. 91, ); while to Tecmessa she is invisible (301). But this, again, would not be inconsistent with Greek belief. In  Athena restores the spear to Achilles, yet is unseen by Hector. In   she appears to Achilles, but the others see her not.

For  as= sight, cp.  (of Aegisthus) :   (in a place out of sight). It may be added that we might suppose Athena to be invisible to Odysseus , without necessarily excluding the idea that she becomes visible to him at a later moment in the dialogue. Thus in    the presence of Artemis is known to Hippolytus only by a divine fragrance, though to the spectators she is doubtless visible; but a little later he beholds her (1440).See Appendix.

p.title: Dict. Ant.
p.#text: . The trumpet meant here was in form like the Roman,straight, gradually increasing in diameter, and ending in a bell-shaped aperture (). Tyrrhenian, a frequent epithet of the trumpet (  ,   ,   , etc.), perhaps means no more than that the instrument was first brought to Europe by Tyrrhenian pirates,the  of Menander (frag.incert. 399). The Tyrrheni, according to a tradition for which Herodotus is the earliest witness (1. 94), were of Lydian origin; and the bronze trumpet may have been a Lydian invention (see  Tuba). Homer mentions the trumpet only in similes, as when the voice of Achilles is likened to it ( , etc.). But the Greeks must have had it as early at least as the time of the Dorian conquest, to judge from the legends heard by Pausanias at Argos (2. 21,  3), where there was a shrine of .See Appendix.

p.#text: This is the form of Parodos used by Aeschylus in the , the , and the  Nearest to this early and simple form is that in which lyric strophes are intermingled with anapaestic systems. A parodos of the latter type is found in the , the , and the

title: Supplices
Persae
Agamemnon
p.#text: The anapaestic march consists here of 38 verses; in the Aeschylean , of 40. It is much longer in the  (64 vv.), and in the  (63).

The Chorus of fifteen Salaminian sailors enter the orchestra from the spectator's right (as they come from their quarters in the Greek camp). They march in three files () of five men each. At the close of the anapaests (v. 171), they form themselves in three ranks () of five each, facing the proscenium.

p.title: Gr. Bhnenalterthmer
p.#text: It can scarcely be doubted that the anapaests were chanted by the whole Chorus, and not by the coryphaeus alone (see  MA. ller, , p. 217, n. 2).

:  . The followers of Ajax call upon him to come forth from his tent, where, for some days previously, he had remained in sullen seclusion (194 f.), and to refute this dire rumour of his onslaught on the cattle. Surely it is a malignant slander. Or is it possible that some angry deity has driven him to such a deed? Assuredly it is abhorrent from his own nature.

p.#text: :  for the place of the second epithet, see n. on  . While  would suggest to an Athenian the narrow strait, so familiar to his sight, which divides Salamis from the Attic mainland, the second epithet, , would, as it were, turn his eyes seaward, inviting him to look forth from the shore of Salamis itself towards the Saronic Gulf. Each adjective lends a touch to the picture. This is thoroughly Greek. See, for instance,   164 , the sandy  of Aulis :  400 ,where the blue expanse, the surge, and the depths beneath it () are all suggested.

p: The sailors ask whether Artemis or Ares can have driven Ajax to such a deed. In connection with their chief, the deities of hunting and war naturally occur to them. They do not think of Athena.

p.#text: =: for the form, cp.   :   . There were two cults of Artemis, originally quite distinct. (1) The  was a goddess who rules over bulls,one of the numerous attributes of Artemis in her relation to wild animals: cp. . A Macedonian silver coin (from Amphipolis) shows her riding on a prancing bull, and carrying a torch in either hand. On another coin she appears (with the inscr. ) carrying two torches, and with the horns of a bull growing out of her shoulders: these horns were meant to suggest the crescent moon. The cult of the Tauropolos was purely Greek, and had nothing fierce or cruel about it. (2) The cult of  Artemis  (or ) had orgiastic elements; it was of Asiatic origin, and belonged to a primitive stage of natureworship. The ritual was a bloody one, and in early times involved human sacrifice. This was the Artemis whose cult was said to have been brought to Brauron in Attica, from the Tauric Chersonese, by Iphigeneia and Orestes.

p.title: Iliad
p.#text: is in the  either the War-god (2. 651), seemingly identical with Ares, or an epithet of Ares (17. 211 ). Like , the word is of uncertain (possibly Thracian) origin. The mention of this deity has a two-fold fitness here; (1) on account of the reference in 178 to Artemis Agrotera; for, acc. to Pollux 8. 91, the Athenian Polemarch made annual offerings : (2) because in the island-home of Ajax there was a   of Enyalios, founded by Solon to commemorate the victory by which Athens wrested Salamis from the Megarians (  ). Further, Enyalios is here supposed to have helped Ajax; whereas Ares usually favoured the Trojans (cp.  ). As to the Attic relationship between the two deities, see Appendix.

The first  falls into two principal parts. In the first (201332), the hero's plight is made clear by the exchange of tidings between Tecmessa and the Chorus, each learning what the other has to tell. In the second part (333595), Ajax himself speaks with the Chorus and Tecmessa; his words foreshadow a resolve to die. The first part opens with a kommos between the Chorus and Tecmessa (201262); the second, with a kommos between the Chorus and Ajax (348429).

p.#text: ; And what heaviness (heavy trouble) has the past night  for the (already grievous) fortune of the day?  in a midd. sense; cp.  Diod. frag. 60 . The fact that  has more often a passive sense in Attic is quite compatible with such an exceptional use; thus Antiphon can say,  (), and  (    8). But it is more doubtful whether such a notion as , or  can here be supplied with . The parallels adduced are such as  (in summer,  ),  ( 1. 202). There was indeed a tendency in Greek idiom to make substantives out of fem. adjectives;  to use the fem. adj. alone, whenever the subst. (such as ) could readily be understood. And that tendency must be considered here.

No tolerable emendation has been made. , stillness, though possible, is very feeble.  (=), which Nauck adopts, is directly contrary to the sense; for, even  the dread rumour arose, the Chorus had been disquieted by the long seclusion and inaction of Ajax (194 f.). , without some further definition (such as ), would be too vague. And the words  suggest that there was some mention of  On the whole, the traditional reading, though difficult, is less open to objection than any remedy which has been proposed.

p.title: Nub.
p.#text: , guiding horses, refers to  in both the other places where it occurs (  , of Hippolytus;   571, of Poseidon Hippius). Here, , closely following , must mean the herdsmen who tended the sheep and oxen (=, 27). It would be forced, then, to suppose that  means  horses,with ref. to the horses of the Greeks on the  (143 f.). That would be as if one said, the cattle, and their herdsmen, who  tended horses. Herdsmen in charge of great flocks and herds, on a wide plain, and near a watchful foe, might well be mounted. It is no objection and least of all, in an Attic tragedy that the Homeric  does not ride. The reading , instead of  (horse-feeding), is made certain by metre (v. 245), and is confirmed by the first hand in L (cr. n.).

: for the rt. ARG, denoting brightness, and its derivatives, cp.   n. As Ajax purposed to  Odysseus (110), the ram which suffers that fate here might naturally be identified with him. The first ram, which is beheaded at once, might then represent Agamemnon; and Menelas would here be ignored. On this view, however, there is a discrepancy with verses 97110, since both the Atreidae are there supposed to be dead, while Odysseus has still to suffer. Here one ram (Agamemnon) is slain, and the other (Odysseus) flogged, in rapid succession.

If the two rams are the two Atreidae, then Odysseus is ignored here. This would be consistent both with vv. 97 110 and with 298306. The flogging of the second ram here would correspond with the words  in 299 f. Then came the colloquy of Ajax with Athena (301); after which, he slowly regained his sanity,before he had inflicted the lash upon Odysseus. That the two rams are here the royal  might be suggested by the analogy of the two eagles in  On the other hand, the special ferocity with which Ajax treats the second ram rather indicates that it represents Odysseus. There would be no point in so distinguishing Menelas from Agamemnon. On the whole, it seems most probable that the poet meant Agamemnon and Odysseus, but was careless of strict consistency with vv. 97110.

. He first shears off the head; then, still holding it, while the carcass drops to the ground, cuts off the end of the tongue; and next hurls both head and tongue from him.  can mean the extremity, the tip, of the tongue, as in : so in   is the heel. It could not mean, the tongue from the roots,  ( ).It was customary to cut out the tongues of animals slain for sacrifice, and to offer them separately ( :   ). But I doubt whether there is any  reference here to the sacrificial custom; the act of Ajax rather expresses merely fierce hatred of a slanderer.

title: Problem.
Iliupersis
p.#text: The words  go with , not with : they stand first, because they express the foremost thought,viz., that the violence of his frenzy is past. Attended by the lightning-flash no more, the storm in his soul is subsiding, after a sharp outburst (), like the wind of the south. A key to these much-discussed verses may be found, I think, in a passage which seems to have been overlooked. The Greeks had observed that, when the  was a stormy wind, it was accompanied by clouds; but, when gentler, by a clear sky:   26. 20 (p. 942  34) . The mood of Ajax is now once more becoming , like the milder south-wind; lately it was like a fierce storm from the south, and , dark with the clouds from which the  of his madness was flashing. Compare the description of the mad Ajax by Arctnus in the  ( Eustath. p. 859. 47), . For other views of this passage, and the attempts to amend it, see Appendix.

p.#text: Ajax, sitting among his victims, and meditating his own destruction, was the subject of a famous picture by Timomachus of Byzantium. Philostratus ( 2. 22  5) thus describes it:  [cp. v. 325 ],   . The picture was at Cyzicus in 70 B.C. (  ), but was afterwards bought by Julius Caesar for the Temple of Venus Genetrix in Rome (  7. 38  126). See Introduction  20.

p: This kommos serves, like the last (201262), as a lyric expression of tragic pathos; after which the situation is further developed, as in the former case, by iambic dialogue. But in one respect this kommos differs from its predecessor. In order to bring the mind of Ajax into fuller relief, the lyrics are given to him alone, while the Chorus and Tecmessa speak only trimeters.
The structure is as follows:1st strophe 348355=1st antistr. 356363: 2nd str. 364378=2nd ant. 379393: 3rd str. 394411=3rd ant. 412429. For the metres see Metrical Analysis.

p.title: Yet
p.#text: The question whether the MSS. have lost a syllable here depends on the view taken of 369. I have given reasons for thinking that the second  in that verse is genuine; from which it would follow that there is a defect here. Bellermann, indeed, is content to hold that Sophocles neglected an exact correspondence; but this seems very unlikely. L. Dindorf's remedy , has this advantage over the others (cr. n.), that it gives a light adversative force, and so fitly responds to v. 383,  Triumph, like defeat, is the gift of heaven. would that I could see him, etc. The next best conjecture is perhaps that of Apitz, .

p.title: Gorg.
p.#text: , a word used by Pindar, Eur. , and Herodotus. The reading  (requiring  instead of  in 372) had an obvious and prosaic motive; viz., that Aeacus, the grandfather of Ajax, was the son of Zeus ( ), so that Zeus could not properly be called an ancestor of the hero's ancestors. But when the poet wrote , it was enough for him that it expressed the  thought, author of my line; he did not trouble himself with this subtlety.It was the nymph Aegina who bore Aeacus to Zeus (  Plat. p. 526 E: ).

The conjectures of various critics are recorded and classified in the Appendix. Here I will briefly state what seem the main points of the problem.

(1) The antistrophic verses, 423427 (), appear sound. The changes which have been proposed in them have all been designed to suit some emendation in 405 ff., and would have no probability if verses 423 ff. were considered simply on their own merits.

(2) There is only one real discrepancy of metre between the traditional text here and that of the antistrophe; viz., that  in 406 answers to the  of  in 424, where the , being the last syllable of a verse, could be either long or short, and is here long. (Some, indeed, read : cr. n.) That is, instead of , we require . As to  in 423, answering to  in 405, we should write . With regard to the  of 405 ff., the most suspicious point is the redundancy , suggesting that one of the words was a gloss upon the other.

p.#text: (3) If, then, we assume that the antistrophe is sound, we may conclude that the fault in the strophe lies within the words . A very slight change will restore the metre, viz.  for : cp. the words of Ajax in 453 . There he points to the slain cattle around him; and so he probably does here also. We could then understand the sense to  be: If those things (, his glories in the past) perish, my friends, ,  (, by the slaughter of) such creatures, , near me there. But  may have been a marginal gloss (on ), which has displaced some other word: , the poet may have written  (cp. v. 453).

quote.#text: ei) ta\ me\n fqi/nei, fi/loi, toi=sd' o(mou= pe/las

p.#text: (4) Whatever may have been the original  of the words , it is at least highly probable that their general sense was, If my old renown is perishing. This is suggested by the other passages where we find the same sequence of ideas,, the thought of his past glory closely followed by that of his present disgrace; see (1) 421427: (2) 437456: (3) 612621.

p: (5) Those who believe that the antistrophic verses 423427 are corrupt have a freer hand for emendation here; and, as will be seen in the Appendix, some of the proposed restorations have been very bold. But such remedies pass into the region of pure guess-work.

p.title: Encyc. Brit.
p.#text: As I have noted in writing on the Troad elsewhere, nearly all the plains and hills are more or less well-wooded. Besides the valonia oak, the elm, willow, cypress and tamarisk shrub abound. Lotus, galingale, and reeds are still plentiful, as in Homeric days, about the streams in the Trojan plain. (, art. Troad, vol. XXIII. p. 578.)
This order of words has the best authority, and is confirmed by the metre. .

p.title: Mendere
p.#text: : cp.  . The Scamander, still called the , is the most important river of the Troad. Rising in Ida, it flows through the central plain which now bears the name of the town Bairamitch, and thence passes  northward into the plain of Troy. On the confines between the two plains, where the river winds in large curves through deep gorges in limestone rocks, its scenery is striking. From the south border of the Trojan plain to the Hellespont, the Mendere has a course of between seven and eight miles.

p.title: Life
p.#text: , the  (not, ) days: the series formed by placing each new day at the side of its predecessors, as  could be said of forming men in rank. The sense is: When a man's miseries are unbroken, , what power to please him has each successive day,  () , when it has brought him close up to death, , and then again moved him back from death? Death is the boundary-line () on the field of life:    (). The man who is captive to evil fortune is like a  on the draughtboard, at one moment moved close up to the line, and then again withdrawn from it a little; but it is death, after all,death and nothing else,that awaits him (). This is not the platitude, all men must die, but a thought sug gested by the case of the man whose woes are unvarying.  has nothing in store for him; the question is merely whether he is to die at once, or to have a short and wretched reprieve. This is brought out by v. 479:  is denied to him; and that being so, the next best thing is to die honourably .

. Destiny, working through Ajax, ravaged her country. Destiny in some other form brought her father and mother to the grave. The poet did not wish to represent Tecmessa as living with the man who had slain her parents; and so followed, or invented, a legend which ascribed their deaths to a different agency. Throughout this speech, the Homeric scene between Hector and Andromach is present to the mind of Sophocles. Andromach's father had been slain by Achilles; her mother, by the visitation of Artemis ( 428).

. The formula  (lit. and verily) introduces a new fact or thought; as in Tragedy it often announces a new comer (1168). When this new fact or thought raises a difficulty in the way of something proposed by the last speaker, then  acquires an adversative force. Thus here, its literal sense, and verily, indeed, is tinged by the context with the sense, oh, but, or nay, but. The effect of  is to place a slight stress on . p.title: Erot. Scriptores
p.#text: [ ] Such an unconsciousness is an evil, as excluding , but painless, as exempt from . This verse was probably written in the margin, as a parallel passage to v. 554, and then crept into the text. It may come (as Valckenr thought) from some other play of Sophocles; its tone seems less suggestive of Euripides. That it was a familiar quotation, may be seen from the way in which it is brought in by the novelist Eustathius (or Eumathius), in  ( 1100 A.D. ?), ch. 2  7 ( vol. II. p. 174 ed. Hercher), . It is translated, along with v. 553, in the sentences of Publilius Syrus ( 45 B.C.), 876 f.,  But those two verses are doubtless later interpolations in the text of Publilius: they are wanting in the best MS. (Monac. lat. 6292).

Ajax adds these words to show that he does not mean Teucer's mother, Hesion (1300). Eriboea was the daughter of Alcathos, king of Megara: Pindar mentions her as the mother of Ajax ( 5. 45). She is called Periboea by Apollodorus (3. 12  7) and Pausanias (1. 42. 1).

p.title: Dict. of Antiquities
p.#text: . This  must be interpreted by the usage of the poet's day, not by Homeric practice. The  may be seen on shields depicted in Greek vase-paintings; an example is reproduced in Smith's  (3rd ed., vol. I. p. 459, art. ). It was a leathern thong, running round the inner edge of the shield, and fixed at intervals of six inches or so by pins or nails, so as to form a succession of loops. The name, , was derived from these pins (), which could be taken out, when it was wished to remove the  and so to unfit the shield for immediate use. (It is made a charge against Cleon in    that he had dedicated the shields taken at Pylos .)

p.title: Helen.
p.#text: But a loop at the edge of the shield, such as the  offered to the warrior's  (  1376 ), would not suffice to give him control. Hence, in the vasepainting noticed above, we see the  combined with another contrivance, viz., a  (of metal, or wood), placed vertically across the inside of the shield, and furnished at the middle with an arrangement of small bars, forming a support for the arm just below the elbow. This band was the  or .See Appendix.

(much, or well, stitched) is a general epithet for elaborate leatherwork, and is again illustrated by the vase-painting cited above, where ornamental tassels hang from the pins which divide the loops of the . In , the epithet probably refers to braiding; quivers were often made of hide or leather.

=epic : see n. on 19. The second part of the compound is not , but , ox-hide ( ). The shield was the work of ,so essentially was the currier's art that which it chiefly demanded ( ). Tychios dwelt at ,probably the Boeotian ( ). The number of  layers of hide was probably exceptional; in  Teucer has a , , with four such layers.

p.#text: . Here, as at 1141, the fut. perf. gives a peremptory tone. Athena uses it in   1464: . (Cp.   1436 .) The ordinary fut. pass. was . The practice of burying a warrior's arms with him was a primitive Aryan custom; witness the swords found in the graves at Mycenae. Sophocles in this play follows the legend that the body of Ajax was , and not, as was the ordinary practice in the heroic age, burned ( n.). The reference to the burial of the arms is thus perfectly fitting. There was less meaning in the practice, noticed by Homer, of  a warrior's armour with him;  :  . It may have come down from the earlier days when interment was the rule. No arms are burned on the pyre of Patroclus (  ff.), Hector (24. 785 ff.), or Achilles (  ff.).

Ajax is now withdrawn into the tent on the eccyclema (), and the entrance is closed. Tecmessa and her child retire by another door into the part of the dwelling which is supposed to represent the . They re-enter after the Choral ode, and are present while Ajax speaks (see 684 ff.). Some, indeed, suppose that they remain on the scene during the ode; but the command of Ajax to Tecmessa in 579 f., , is against this.

p.title: Rhein. Mus.
p.#text: Welcker thinks that not only Tecmessa (with the child), but Ajax also, remain present during the ode. ( for 1829, part 3, p. 87.) It is clear, however, from v. 593 that Ajax withdraws into the tent.

p.#text: If this passage cannot be restored with certainty, at least the doubt lies within narrow limits. Three points should be noted.

1. The metre (logaoedic) is clear: no suspicion rests on the antistrophic verses, 613615 . Metre proves, then, that () instead of L's , we require , which is given by . () Instead of  we require , which is satisfied by . () Instead of , we require .
2. , as a correction of , may be regarded as certain. Sophocles would have written . It is  confirmed by the fact that our best MS., L, has , not .
3. , as a correction of , is (to my mind) not less certain. For , cp.  () . In no other way can  be justified.

What remains doubtful, then, is only how we should correct the words, . Now, in favour of , let it be noted that, if  was the genuine word, then the corruption of  into  is at once explained; for  meant properly a fold for cattle, as in  , where it is synonymous with . Here, however, it would have the general sense which it bears in  , , dwellings,a sense in which  too was poetically used. No other conjecture accounts for the origin of .

p.#text: , notwithstanding  in 600. Tennyson's poem, , begins thus:Courage! he said, and pointed toward the land,  This mounting wave will roll us shoreward soon.  In the afternoon they came unto a land  In which it seemed always afternoon. The repetition of the word land there was deliberate, being designed to suggest languor. Sophocles doubtless had no such conscious aim here; he was simply indifferent, as so often, to the recurrence (  n.); but something of a like effect is actually produced. p.#text: (if sound) means life, not merely as=living man, but in the sense of life-destiny: cp.  . The strict meaning would be then, no life-destiny which the line of Aeacus has known. There is a certain pathos in this which may plead for it as against Reiske's very plausible emendation  ( for A), which may be right, though, as compared with , it is perhaps a little weak. Cp.  .

Second . Ajax comes forth from the tent, and addresses his faithful friends. The speech translates his unshaken purpose into the terms of his altered mood; yet so as to veil his meaning from the hearers, and to make them think that not only the mood, but the purpose, is changed. (See Introduction,  12.) Tecmessa who left the scene at 595, now returns, entering on the right of the spectators, and leading her child. Their presence adds effect to v. 653; and Ajax addresses her at v. 684.

p.title: Iliad
p.#text: Calchas is present at this council, as he is at that in the first book of the  ( ). He knew by inspiration that, if Ajax could be kept in his tent for that one day, all would be well. Leaving the circle of the chiefs, he went to Teucer, who was awaiting the result in the neighbourhood. They sat down apart (). The messenger was near them, and heard what Calchas said to Teucer.

p.#text: . The primitive sense of the root () was to press: whence come both the meanings of this verb, to shut out, and to shut in.  Acc. to Eustathius (p. 1387. 3) the Attic form was  as= (shut out or hinder), but  as=. Curtius (  142) thinks that this distinction was of comparatively late origin. Our MSS. consistently give , a prison.  Andoc. or. 4  27 has  (imprisoning):   Plat. p. 45 E  (indeed, the forms from  are always aspirated). But in regard to the other forms the evidence of MSS. is often conflicting, and the practice of editors has varied. In Thuc. , Bekker always writers : Classen and Stahl, always , even () in 8. 74  3  and 4. 47  3 , where the ref. is to imprisonment; though in the latter place the MSS. seem to agree on . On the other hand in    the best editions give .  Eur. Itmay be noted that Lobeck could find no instance of  earlier than Aelian ( 12. 21 ): as to  in   , he justifies it as meaning, shut in (apart), not shut off. Recent editors are generally agreed in writing  here, and  in 795. This is justifiable in any case, the sense being to , rather than definitely to

p.#text: To judge the text aright here, we must remember that these are the words of the , who speaks as the prophet of the gods.  are mortals whose over-great strength and success have made them wax too proud, so that they no longer serve the gods with due piety. Such mortals are  ,their lives can yield no worthy fruit. Compare the words of warning addressed to Xerxes ( ): . See also v. 1077, : and Athena's phrase in 129, .

It is not without reason, then, that the reading  is supported by the general consensus of ancient testimony.  is adopted by several recent editors, because the  of Ajax is elsewhere recognised (763 , 766 ), whereas he could not, they think, be called . But that depends on the point of view. In the sight of the gods, the greatest warrior would be , if he ceased . Observe, too, that the word  confirms : the idea is that of greatness which, swollen beyond the human limit, has ceased to fulfil the proper function of mankind. Such  are   .

p.#text: , immediately on rising from his seat beside Calchas (750 n.). No sooner had Calchas finished, than Teucer rose, and sent the messenger, who was close by,sitting among the .  (Cp.  ,in the agora.) Some take  as= immediately,  his seat,, without rising (so that he would beckon or call the man to him): cp.  :  () , even there as they sat. But in those phrases  helps to fix the sense: whereas  following  regularly denotes the point from which the further action sets out (, etc.). Hence   to mean, immediately  sitting. Other explanations of  are: (1) from where I (the messenger) sat. (2) After the sitting of the council. But Teucer would not wait for that. (3) Leaving the council (or strictly, its neighbourhood, since Calchas had come apart from it,  Od. 750). This would imply that Teucer had been included in the : but the tone used towards him by Menelas (1120 ) and Agamemnon (1235 ) makes this very unlikely.

p: Teucer sends a messenger, instead of going himself, probably because he hopes that his mediation with the chiefs may do some good. What he dreads is simply that Ajax should leave the tent; and a message could prevent that. He has no cause to suspect that Ajax meditates suicide.

The fear which had haunted Tecmessa from the moment when Ajax regained his sanity (326), and which his words had lulled, has been revived by the message of Calchas. The definite expression of that fear, by , is a fitting close to this scene, and prepares for the next.

As to the diction of the verse, three points claim notice. (1) The  after  emphasises, not that word, but the whole clause, . Cp.   f.,  f.:  :  It contrasts  with  . (2)  is the original reading to which L's points (cr. n.). It generalises the statement. (3) , which was written by the first hand in L, is in its turn supported by  as against : for, if the sentiment is general, it will depend on  more fitly than on . In  this case, the acc.  depends on  as=, a constr. quite possible for poetry: cp.   f.  (n.).

p.title: Gr. Bhnenalterthmer
p.#text: A change of scene is now supposed to take place, from the ground in front of the tent of Ajax to a lonely spot on the sea-shore, with trees or bushes (, 892). We do not know how this change was managed. (1) It may have been indicated merely by removing the hangings on the back-wall which represented the  of Ajax. This is  MA. ller's view (, p. 162). (2) Wecklein supposes that a back-wall, representing the , was drawn back on right and left, disclosing the new scene.We cannot assume the use of  in the poet's time (cp. note at the beginning of the play). Had they been in use, the  on the spectator's left could have turned, so as to represent a new locality (). The right-hand , indicating the region in which the whole action takes place (), would not have been changed.

p.title: Eumenides
p.#text: The only other Greek play in which a change of scene is certain is the , where the action begins at the temple of the Delphian Apollo, and passes at v. 235 to that of Athena Polias at Athens. This may have been marked merely by substituting a statue of Athena for one of Apollo.

p.#text: Ajax is standing at the side of the scene on the spectator's right, near the underwood which screens him when he fallsso that his body is not at first visible to the Chorus when they return to the orchestra, but could be seen by Tecmessa, when she comes on the scene from the left. The point of the sword could probably be seen by the audience. Hesychius quotes Polemon, the sophist in Hadrian's age, as saying that the  was used . It was a short stage-sword, of which the blade ran back; otherwise called  (Hesych., which some refer to ), or . Cp. Achilles Tatius 3. 20 .
The antithesis to    is delayed: it is given by  in 823. Meanwhile, the reasons why the weapon should prove deadly have been developed in three clauses (). Hence  is resumed in 823 by .
here is simply the slayer. In    are sacrificial knives.

p: The last two of these four verses are certainly spurious, as three things show.

p.#text: (1) The poet would not have made the dying Ajax pray that the Atreidae may die at the hands of their offspring, unless there had been some legend that they so died. But, according to the current mythology, Agamemnon was slain by his wife and her paramour, while Menelas and Helen passed, without dying, to Elysium ( ). It is only in later times that we meet with the story of Menelas and Helen having been sacrificed by Iphigeneia in the land of the Tauri (, cp. ): a myth which the author of these verses may have had in view. Odysseus, indeed, was slain by Telegonus; but he does not come into account here, unless we make the improbable change of  to  in 838. [As to the double sense of , with ref. to one who is slain (1) by himself, (2) by a kinsman, see on  .]
(2) These two verses confuse the construction, since  ( ) refers to what precedes: while  in 841 refers to .
(3) The form  occurs nowhere else, except as a proper name.

p.#text: A more difficult question is whether vv. 839, 840 are also spurious. The schol. in L on v. 841 is as follows:: . As the lemma, , clearly indicates,  refers only to the two verses 841 f., and not (as Dindorf and others have assumed) to all the four verses 839842. The surmise was, says the scholiast, that vv. 841 f. were added to make the meaning clearer; , to explain the elliptical phrase, . Such a surmise itself shows that vv. 839, 840 were believed to be older than 841 f. It is indeed plain that all four verses are not by the same author. The incoherent construction noticed above, under (2), was possible for an interpolator whose attention was fixed on , but hardly for one who was forging vv. 839842 as a whole. If, then, all four verses are condemned, we must assume two independent interpolations.

I incline to think that the two verses 839 and 840 are genuine; because, otherwise, the imprecation on the  (844) would follow too abruptly on v. 838. The prayer for the destruction  of his chief foes, uttered in 839 f., leads up to the more sweeping denunciation of the Greek army.

(see n. on 813 f.). The  which has been searching the westward bays now reenters the orchestra by the parodos on the spectator's right, and a moment or two later the other  comes in at the opposite side.

The extant examples of hemichoria in Tragedy are not many. In    ff., after the collective lament of the Chorus for the house of Laus, one semichorus expresses sympathy with Antigone, while the other elects to obey Creon. In    ff. the two hemichoria are supposed to guard the  E. and W. sides of the palace. In  111, 232 the Chorus which bewails Alcestis is divided into two parts merely for the sake of the antiphonal dirge. Sophocles adopts a like arrangement in  870, where, as here, no actor is present.

: , and n. on    . The dialogue in 866878 is conducted by the two leaders of hemichoria. When Sophocles raised the number of the tragic Chorus  from twelve to fifteen, his object was to provide a coryphaeus (distinct from the ordinary choreutae), and two subordinate leaders. The technical name for these leaders of hemichoria was , because they stood one on each side of the coryphaeus when the Chorus was drawn up in ranks ().

p.#text: For the sentiment, cp. Mimnermus fr. 1 (in Nauck's  2nd ed., p. 829) .

p: Various theories of interpolation have been held with regard to this passage: see Appendix. Most of them are founded on the assumption that Tecmessa's former speech of ten lines (915924) must be balanced by a speech of the same length here, and that therefore three of the thirteen verses (961 973) must be struck out. (Nauck, who rejects 918 f., strikes out five verses here, 966970.)
As several objections arise from the alleged incoherence of the speech, it is well to observe the train of thought in 961973.

p.#text: Let them mock, if they will, at the fate of Ajax; they will perhaps find out, in time of need, what they have lost; foolish men never know their own good fortune till they have thrown it away  (961965). No, his death is no gain for themthough it is anguish for me: for , it is the release which he desired (966968). Why should they mock at him, then? They cannot even claim that his death was their work; it is the affair of the gods (969 f.). So Odysseus may exult, if he pleases, but it is an empty triumph. He and his friends have merely suffered a ; Ajax is gone, and has left nothing behind him but the sorrow which is mine (971973).

p.#text: . There is no other example of  as first word of a verse. It is usually read as first word of a clause in   399 () ..; where, however, Dindorf gives  ( being a variant for ). There is, however, no reason to doubt it here. With Sophocles the words sometimes run on from the end of one trimeter to the beginning of the next, as if there were no break between the verses. See  1089 :  :  :   (Such elision at the end of the verse was remarked by the ancients as peculiar to Sophocles: see on  ) The place of  here is only another example of the same tendency, and is illustrated by that of  in  . This virtual synaphea of trimeters naturally occurs most often in passages where, as here, the speech is excited or rapid.

. On learning that Ajax had left the tent, the Messenger and others had hastened to the camp, to inform Teucer (804). They knew nothing as to the hero's fate. Teucer, who had stayed near the council of chiefs in the hope of mediating (780), then set out to seek Ajax,going, not, of course, to the tent itself, but to the coast near it. While engaged in the search, he heard the rumour that Ajax was dead.

p.#text: As a matter of verbal criticism, it might be observed that  and  confirm each other. But the defence of the text rests on broader ground. Evidently we must either reject the whole passage 1028 1039, as Morstadt and Nauck do, or else leave this verse unaltered. For the parallel between the sword and the girdle, as fatal to their respective recipients, would fail altogether, if the girdle had not been an agent of  to Hector, but merely of insult to his corpse. It is not known whence Sophocles derived this version, which so strangely mars the very climax of the ; possibly from one of the two Cyclic epics, the  of Arctnus or the  of Lesches, which related the  (see Introd.  2, 3). One thing, at least, seems hardly doubtful. The original motive of this version must have been the same which prompts its use by Sophocles here, viz., to point the fatal character of Hector's gift to Ajax by connecting a like result with the gift of Ajax to Hector. Two epigrams, attributed to Leontius Scholasticus ( 550 A.D. ), turn on the same legend ( 7. 151, 152): see Appendix.

p.#text: , the toiling , the born subjects of Menelas, who are bound to endure the labours of war in any field to which their lord calls them. Cp.   ,  ,where  are the rank and file. The strangeness which has been felt in the phrase, , will perhaps be lessened if we remember how habitually the Attic poets transfer the associations of their own time to the heroic age. In picturing the followers of the Spartan king, Sophocles may have had in mind the Perioeci who served as hoplites and the Helots who served as light-armed in the armies of their Spartan masters.
Assuredly  does not mean busybodies, , as some have taken it,supposing it to be said scornfully of  tributary to Menelas and eager to display their zeal.

p.#text: (=), the reading of A, is distinctly preferable  to , though the latter has the support of the first hand in L. With  the sense would be: It were shameful if people should hear that  to use force is chastising only by words. We must not be misled by the analogy of the Latin subjunctive:  could be merely an allusive way of saying  but the Greek equivalent of  would be () , not . In 1081,  (), the subjunctive is fitting: but not so here, where the reference is to a definite person  who has a certain power.  is not, indeed, impossible: it is, however, so unnatural in this context that it would require much stronger authority to support it as against .

p.title: Dionys.
p.#text: , from , mould: an epithet applied in epic poetry to the nether world, where all things moulder in damp, cheerless gloom:  (, the home of Hades) .  . Simonides illustrates this sense (fr. 4. 4), : and Vergil reproduces it ( ) in his , the rough and mouldering wilderness of the underworld. Quintus Smyrnaeus 14. 241 has . But in later antiquity a false etymology connected  with : thus Hesychius,  , gives  as one explanation of it. Oppian ( 180 A.D. ) actually uses the word in the sense of wide,  : and so too Nonnus (5th cent. A.D. )  25. 476. Among these rites would be the washing and dressing of the corpse (  etc.), in which Tecmessa would naturally bear part, and the pouring of , in which Eurysaces also would share. The dual  is therefore right: Wakefield's conjecture , which Nauck adopts, implies that the work was to be Teucer's alone. Cp.  :  .

While the child knelt as a suppliant by the body, with his hand upon it, the corpse could not be forcibly removed without offence to Zeus . Teucer is about to go and seek a place for the grave (1184), and he desires to secure that the body shall not be disturbed during his absence.

p.#text: , offerings to the dead, as in  , where the locks of hair are laid on the corpse (). So in   f. Chrysothemis is told to lay locks of her own hair and her sister's on Agamemnon's tomb,the significance of the act being marked by the prayer which is to follow the gift:  (453 f.). In its primitive symbolism the severed hair meant that the person from whose head it was cut devoted himself to the dead, and (as it were) escorted him to the  shades; the gift of hair being a substitute for self-immolation at the grave.

title: Demi of Attica

Demi
Athens and Attica
p.#text: : for the  of  before , cp.  .Sunium, the S. E. promontory of Attica, is, in Leake's words, lofty, steep, and rugged on every side, except the south-west, where there is a beach and a small bay, with an island at the entrance (, vol. II. p. 63). On the highest point stood the Doric temple of Athena, built probably about the middle of the 5th century B.C. The modern name of the cape,  (), is derived from the remaining columns of the temple, which are of a brilliant whiteness, the marble of which they are made being of a much lighter colour than the Pentelic. As seen from a distance,  glittering in the sun across the blue sea, they look like pillars of snow or salt, rather than stone (Mure,  II. p. 123). Cp.    (where the epithet alludes to the silver-mines of Laurium). Poseidon also was worshipped at Sunium (,   ): but Leake was disposed to think that he can have had an altar only, as the sole buildings traceable were the temple of Athena and the fortress erected on Sunium  413 B.C. ( II. p. 64). Wordsworth, however, saw remains which, he thought, might be those of a Poseidonion (, p. 177).

, being naught (a simple statement): , for him who is  naught. The only difference between the two expressions is that the phrase with  is, in effect, somewhat more emphatic, and (here) more bitter, since it implies a mental act of comparison, with the result of deciding that this particular person is  a nonentity. The angry king scorns Teucer, but his bitterness is against the dead Ajax. The phrase with  is, of course, equally applicable to the dead ( , ), and that with  to the living (above, , ).   (n.).

Agamemnon speaks throughout of , meaning Menelas and himself. Teucer had implicitly acknowledged that Agamemnon was commander-in-chief (1105). But he denied that Menelas had any authority over Ajax (1100), and also that either of the two Atreidae had a right to forbid the burial (1109).

p.#text: (1) There is strong evidence that the term  was used in the 5th cent. B.C. to denote a raised deck, a quarter-deck, at the stern of the ship. This is clear in  :  Arion asks leave, : the officers of the ship consent, and are then said , leaving  Arion alone on the . In   1571, : which is clearly a place distinct from that where the rowers sat; of them it is said, . (For further evidence on this point, see Appendix.)

p.#text: (2)  denotes the position of the  at the extremities, or sterns, of the ships. Though the  is not closely followed here, Sophocles may probably have had in mind how the Trojans fired the ship of Protesilas  . In   it is said of Hector, ,the crowning ensigns (, ) at the sterns.  might also mean topmost,the  being a  deck. This, however, would suggest rather flames  to a great height; but in   f., where Hector grasps the , it appears that even this can have been only some 7 to 9 feet from the ground, and that the  at the stern (the Homeric equivalent of  here) can have stood only about 5 feet from the ground. (See Dr  Warre E. in Smith's , 3rd ed., vol. II. p. 211 , art. )

p.title: Helen.
p.#text: (3) , after , is pleonastic, if  be explained as above; whereas, if  meant the rowers' seats,  could mean, belonging to the . This is a fair objection to the interpretation given above. But in reply to it we may observe:(1) the word  means dwellings, abodes in  ,   ,  The nautical sense occurs (apart from  ) only here, and in   1571,  Hence the distinctive epithet is intelligible. (2) Further, as the purport of the passage is to mark the urgency of the danger to the ships, on which the ultimate safety of the Greeks depended, there is excuse for the emphatic iteration, .

p: Other views of the passage, and some emendations which have been proposed, will be found in the Appendix.

p.#text: . The situation described here  does not exactly correspond with anything in the  Ajax, indeed, distinguishes himself in repulsing the Trojans after they have come over the wall, and on one occasion wounds their leader Hector (  ff.); but this happens before any ship has been set on fire. The supreme crisis in this part of the  is the moment when the Trojans set fire to the ship of Protesilas (16. 122); but just then Ajax is driven back ( ); it is Patroclus who, urged by Achilles, then comes to the front, and finally beats back the foe. Nor has the  directly furnished the picture of Hector leaping high over the trench.

p.#text: Sophocles may have had some other source, epic or lyric. But it seems equally possible that he wrote from a general recollection of the , without caring whether he reproduced its details. Indeed, two verses of the  might alone have sufficed to suggest the picture which he has drawn,that which says of Ajax,  (15. 731),and the verse which describes Hector leading the Trojans from the Greek wall towards the ships, (13. 53).

This excellent emendation (by Madvig) of the obscure  is irresistibly commended by those very words of Agamemnon to which Teucer refers (1237),  The origin of the corruption may have been the effacement of the H in MH, giving rise to , when  would be altered into  to satisfy the metre.  has been explained: (1) to come and join thee on the field of danger. But, even if  could bear this sense, Agam. could not say that Ajax had never fought on his side at Troy. (2) To meet the foe,  : which is plainly untenable. Agamemnon had asked merely, what has Ajax done  Teucer has replied by referring to the crisis at the ships; and now drives his point home.

p.title: Iliad
p.#text: This combat between Hector and Ajax is told in  7. 38312. Hector having challenged a Greek champion, nine Greek chiefs offered themselves; lots were cast, and the honour fell to Ajax. Hector and Ajax fought till nightfall, when they were parted by heralds, and exchanged gifts (1029 n.).

p.#text: The  ordinary  was a stone or a potsherd, which its owner marked ( ). Ajax did not seek to avoid being drawn by putting in, as his , a piece of damp earth, which would stick to the bottom of the helmet or fall to pieces. Such a  is called , a , because it eludes the ordeal. The allusion is to the story of Cresphontes. After the Dorian conquest of the Peloponnesus, he, Temenus, and the heirs of Aristodemus agreed to cast lots. The first was to have Argos; the second, Lacedaemon; the third, Messenia. Cresphontes wished to have Messenia. He therefore put a lump of earth, as his , into the voting urn. It broke to pieces, so that only the two other  came out. ( .) The scholiast remarks on the anachronism (): so, too, does Eustathius (p. 361. 26).

p.#text: : Arop, daughter of Catreus, king of Crete, a descendant of Minos. According to the legend which Sophocles follows here, Catreus found Arop with a paramour (a slave), and sent her to Nauplius, king of Euboea, charging him to drown her. Nauplius, however, spared her life, and she afterwards married Atreus. The scholiast on 1297 says that this was the story treated by Euripides in the  (Nauck  p. 501); with the difference, however, that Arop married Pleisthenes, not Atreus. The  was produced in 438 B.C. title: Atreus

p.#text: can mean only the father of Arop, Catreus. Now, according to the schol. on   , Sophocles (in a play not named there, but which was probably the ) somewhere described  himself as drowning his false wife for a twofold crime,adultery with Thyestes, and the theft of the golden lamb: . Hence it has been proposed to change  into  (Hermann), or  (Wolff). A simpler correction would be, . But it cannot be assumed that Sophocles must have followed here the same version which he used elsewhere. In his , for example, he appears to have modified the version of the  which he adopts in his  (see  , Introd., p. xliii, n. 4). The story of Arop's detection by Catreus is effective for the purpose here, which is to represent Agamemnon as born of a mother who had sinned before his birth. Nor is that story necessarily inconsistent with the other, that she was false to Atreus, and was drowned by him.

Teucer speaks, with bitter scorn, as if he did not know or care to which of the brothers Helen belonged: at any rate, it is  war, and she is the pretext of it. Eustathius (p. 754. 21) thinks that this touch was suggested to Sophocles by the scornful phrases in which Achilles refers to the  Atreidae, when he speaks of himself as , for their lady-loves' sakes,and asks,  Teucer speaks, at any rate, in the same vein. The words of Eustathius prove that he read , and that he understood the text in the manner explained above: .

p.#text: , adv.: 34 f.The sense of  here is shown by that of : , the one means to help in tying a knot; the other, to help in loosing it. If thou hast come, not not to embroil the feudbut to aid in solving it.  is also said of bringing opponents    479 : but here the metaphor is from a knot. Our word embroil exactly fits  here, since its primary sense is to entangle or perplex (, ). (The phrase in   cannot properly be compared: see n. there.)

p.#text: . This is the first symptom that Agamemnon's resolve has been shaken: he feels dimly that there is a conflict of duties. As a king, he must uphold the common weal, and punish treason (such as Ajax seemed guilty of). It is  to do that. But what if, in doing so, he violates  on another side,that represented by the  of which Odysseus spoke (1343)? A somewhat similar utterance of Agamemnon, when perplexed by the demands upon him, occurs in fr. 481: .

p.#text: : Yes, for with me his worth is far more potentweighs far morethan his enmity.  is a genitive of comparison, depending on the notion of superiority contained in : =. There is no parallel for such a genitive after : but it is quite intelligible, and seems not too bold for the poet's style. (Eustathius p. 842. 10 takes  as depending on :.)

It is very improbable that the text is corrupt. The context in verses 1355 f. at once proves that the words  and  are genuine; and the article before  confirms . As  also is presumably sound, the fault, if any, would have to be sought in , for which neither  nor  is a tolerable substitute; or else in . Now in a reply to the question,  we should expect some reference by Odysseus to his own feeling; and v. 1358 () further indicates that in the preceding verse he actually did refer to himself. Hence the only correction of  which would solve the difficulty of the genitive, viz. , is unsatisfactory.

Odysseus is here replying to the taunt that he is , inconstant. It is common enough for friendship to turn into bitterness. When, therefore, I forget the later enmity of Ajax, and remember only his good service, I am merely condoning a very ordinary change. p.#text: . Many editors place a colon after , explaining the phrase as a proverb: It is always so: every man works for himself. One of the later scholia gives this view: . (Cp. I still prefer the simpler view that  is adverbial: in all things alike every man works for himself. Even in the matter of giving burial to another man a selfish motive enters. . Odysseus cannot be allowed to touch the body, or to assist in carrying it to the grave, or to join in pouring the  at the time of interment. It is this intimate participation which is poetically expressed by the phrase . (Morstadt wished to read  instead of , but this would unduly narrow the sense.)

On the other hand, Odysseus is at liberty to assist in protecting the funeral from interruption by the Greek army. He may be a spectator of the rites, though not a participator; and he may bring with him () any one he pleases. This is what seems to be meant by : where it should be noted that  is not both (as if answering to the  in ), but emphasises the verb,in all else  cooperateas you wish to do. That is,  alludes to the request of Odysseus in 1378 f., , and must therefore refer, in part at least, to something connected with the obsequies not  to friendly offices of a different kind, such as care for Tecmessa and Eurysaces; though it may include these.

It might be unpleasing to the spirit of the dead if Odysseus were allowed to touch the body,  or to have any active part in the rites. So in   ff. the spirit of Agamemnon is conceived as refusing Clytaemnestra's  at his grave; and in the same play, when (1123) Electra is allowed to handle the funeral urn, the pretended Phocian justifies the boon by saying that she is evidently not  to the dead. The wrath of Ajax against Odysseus was conceived as enduring in the world below:  ( )when Odysseus approached.

During his brief absence from the scene (vv. 11851222), Teucer has fulfilled the charge given by the Chorus (1165), and has chosen the spot where Ajax is to be buried. He now directs some of the  Salaminian sailors to go and dig the grave; others are to place the tripod near it; a third detachment is to bring thither the hero's armour from the tent. Tecmessa and Eurysaces are still kneeling beside the corpse (1171 ff.). Verses 1409 ff. mark the moment when the body is lifted from the ground. Then it is borne forth (probably by Teucer and one or more ), the Chorus following, before they separate to their several tasks.

The threefold command () may have been the signal for some corresponding movement on the part of the Chorus; perhaps for the usual change from the formation in three  (), facing the actors, to that in three  (), preparatory to the final exit. Wecklein thinks that the three divisions of the Chorus made separate exits (right, left, and in front of the spectators). This seems less probable, as the closing scene would be more effective if the whole Chorus went out in procession after the body of Ajax.

In vv. 918 f. blood was said to be issuing from his nostrils, and from the wound. There, in the phrase , the context shows that  means upward (from the lower part of the body) to the nostrils. Here, however,  seems to have a more general sense,upward to the surface (whether through the nostrils, or from the mouth of the wound). As Ajax must now have been dead for about an hour, the thing described seems impossible.

p.#text: . If the text is sound, we must supply , as  indicates: lit., toiling for this heroic man, and never yet (having toiled) for a worthier. This is a harsh kind of compression; but, as the general sense is so clear, it might be tolerated. The phrase cannot be explained by attraction, as if , could mean, . Blaydes writes, . As to metre, the verse is a correct paroemiac, , an anapaestic dimeter short of one syllable (catalectic); the only peculiarity is the dactyl in the first foot, which in that place of a paroemiac is less usual than a spondee or an anapaest.

[.] Either this verse is spurious (as is now generally thought), or else both it and verse 1416 are corrupt. If v. 1416 is a  paroemiac, it cannot be followed by a paroemiac. If, then, v. 1417 is to be retained, v. 1416 must be made into an anapaestic dimeter. Further, v. 1417, as it stands, yields no satisfactory sense. It must be taken in one of two ways: (1) by itself, a colon or stop being placed after :I speak of Ajax, in the days when he lived: for the genitive, . Or (2) in connexion with v. 1416, a colon being placed after , but no point after :and never yet (having toiled) for a worthier man than Ajax;I speak of the time when he lived. (Cp. Meleager  22 .) The interpolation of v. 1417 may have been prompted by the comparative , and by a wish to find the name of the hero at the close of the play. No emendation yet proposed is probable: see Appendix.
